title-group.subtitle: Good News, Bad News, No News

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Bob Papper is the Lawrence Stessin distinguished professor of journalism and chair of the department of journalism, media studies, and public relations at Hofstra University and has worked extensively in radio and TV news.

body.p: The 2009–2010 Radio-Television News Directors Association (RTNDA)/Hofstra University annual survey found that the percentage of minority news directors rose in both television and radio. But those were nearly the only positive numbers in the survey. Overall, the percentage of minorities in both radio and television fell for the third straight year, although the drop in TV was small.

Women in radio news rose slightly, but the percentage of women radio news directors went down, as did both the overall percentage of women in TV news and women TV news directors. The drop in women TV news directors was small and the percentage of women TV news directors stood at the second-highest level ever.

As far as minorities were concerned, the bigger picture remained unchanged. In the last 20 years, the minority population in the United States has risen 9.4%; but the minority workforce in TV news was up 2.4%, and the minority workforce in radio was actually half what it was two decades ago (see Table 1). Still, TV news diversity remains far ahead of newspaper (see Table 2), where the 2010 survey by the American Society of News Editors found that minority journalists make up 13.3% of newsroom employees at daily newspapers. That is down 0.1% from the 2009 number.

body.p: For the second year in a row, the percentage of minorities in television decreased from the year before (see Table 3). In fact, we ended the decade with no gains whatsoever for minorities in TV news, and the percentage of minorities in radio news went down substantially (see Table 4).

In TV, much of the drop in minority employment—and Hispanics specifically—came from a drop at Hispanic stations. Among non-Hispanic stations, minority employment slipped by just 0.3 to 19.3%, down from last year’s 19.6%.
At non-Hispanic stations, the minority breakdown was:

list-item.p: 0.5% Native American (unchanged from the year before).

body.p: Overall, 73.9% of the TV news workforce at Hispanic stations were Hispanic. That was up slightly from the previous year’s 72%. Twenty percent were white; 3.5% were Asian American; 2.6% were African American. That was down for white and black and up for Asian American.

As usual, men outnumbered women for almost all groups except Asian Americans, where women outnumbered men 1.5:1 and Native Americans, which were even. Otherwise, differences among Hispanics 3.6% male to 2.2% female; whites: 48.6% to 31.2%; blacks 6.7% to 4.8%.
In radio, the percentage of minorities fell substantially. All groups dropped except Native American.

The overall percentage of minority news directors in TV increased by almost 2% in 2009–2010 (see Table 5). It was still below the all-time high, but it was certainly among the highest percentages I have seen. Much of that was fueled by a jump in Asian American news directors. Historically, minority news directors have been concentrated in the largest markets. It was still highest in markets 1–25, but the percentages were in double digits for all market sizes except 51–100. That was a first. The percentage was still lowest at the largest stations—just 2.8% minority in newsrooms of 51+ staffers. Fox affiliates had the highest percentage at 15.8%, followed by CBS at 10.8%. Both ABC and NBC affiliates were between 6 and 7%. Still, the big four network affiliates, overall, had 9.7% minority news directors. That is up from 6.9% the year before. As usual, minority news directors were most common in the South and West and least likely in the Midwest.

At non-Hispanic TV stations, the percentage of minority news directors rose from the previous year’s 7% to 8.9%. That is just off the all-time high of 9.1% in 2008. African American were 3.2%; 2.5% each for Hispanic and Asian American; and 0.7% Native American. That was about the same for African American and Native American and up for Hispanic and Asian American.

The percentage of minority news directors in radio tripled from the previous year’s paltry 2.2% to this year’s 7% (see Table 6). All minority groups went up except Asian American, which slid slightly. Group-owned stations were less likely to have minority news directors than independent stations.

At 28.4%, the percentage of women TV news directors fell 0.7% from the previous year’s all-time high of 29.1% (see Table 7). It was still the second-highest percentage ever. It’s also worth emphasizing that the percentage of women TV news directors in the RTNDA/Hofstra University Annual Survey was based on a complete station census—not projected from a smaller sample. So, 28.4% was not a rough figure, it was an exact one. Women news directors were highest in the Midwest and then West and lowest in the South. There was no meaningful difference based on network affiliation.

tr.th: Average Number of Women on Staff

body.p: Women have been right around the 40% mark of the TV workforce for more than a decade. In 2009, the number edged up to 41.4%, but in 2010 it went back down to 40.0%. That could indicate that women in TV news lost their jobs at a higher rate than men, but it could also just be an anomaly in the numbers. Perhaps, I will have the answer after next year’s survey.

Readers with sharp eyes might wonder how women can be in all stations based on staff size but in smaller percentages based on market size. That is because I have all market sizes for all stations, but quite a few stations did not tell me exact staff size. All the stations that supply staff size reported having women in the news department, but that was not the case for all stations that returned the survey. That kind of disparity does not happen often, but it is one of the hazards in survey research.

A mixed picture for women in radio news in 2010 (see Table 8). The percentage of women in the radio workforce stayed essentially the same (up by 1.0%). The percentage of stations with women rose by 10%, but the percentage of women radio news directors fell by 9%. The opposite of the previous year, women were actually more likely to be news director at stations with larger staffs but less likely to be in the Northeast than elsewhere in the country.

body.p: Major markets are those with 1 million or more listeners. Large markets are from 250,000 to 1 million. Medium markets are 50,000–250,000. Small markets are fewer than 50,000.

Minority numbers in TV news presented a mixed picture (see Table 9). The percentage of minority TV news directors rose by almost 2% in the last year to one of the highest levels ever. At the same time, the overall minority workforce dropped by about a percent and a half, and there was a large, puzzling drop in the percentage of stations with minorities. I suspect the latter number was an aberration that will disappear in the next survey.

tr.th: Average Number of Minorities on Staff

body.p: There are few consistent trends within the minority data. Generally, the larger the market, the higher percentage of minorities. Fox affiliates were a little more likely than other network affiliates to have minority news directors, and ABC and NBC affiliates were least likely to have minority news directors. As usual, stations in the South and West were more likely to have minority news directors, and stations there also tended to have a higher percentage of minorities in the newsroom.

Even as the percentage of the minority workforce in radio news fell to one of its lowest levels ever, the percentage of minority radio news directors rose substantially from the previous year (see Table 10). At 7.1%, the percentage of minority radio news directors was not the highest it has been, but it’s certainly on the high end of the scale.

tr.th: Average Number of Minorities on Staff

body.p: Both minority and women general manager (GM) numbers were up slightly from a year ago, but they looked a lot like the year before (see Table 11). Women GMs (at stations that run local news) were more likely to be found in smaller newsrooms and at ABC affiliates and less likely in the Northeast.

At 2.7% in 2008–2009, it was hard to imagine that minority GMs (at network affiliates that run local news) could become even more white, but they did. In 2009–2010, under 2% of those GMs were minorities. The overall percentage of minority went up slightly because minorities at independent stations went up. Among the network affiliates, ABC and NBC stations were much higher than CBS or Fox—but all were low.

At non-Hispanic stations (which run local news), minority GM numbers were cut by one third from the year before . . . which was down two thirds from the year before that. Minority GMs at non-Hispanic stations have gone from 9.8% to 3.1% to 2.6% in this survey. Most of those are black. Seventy percent of the GMs at Hispanic stations were Hispanic; the rest were white.

Both minority and women GM numbers in radio went up in this survey (see Table 12). Both were more likely to be found at noncommercial stations and independent stations. Minority GMs were also most likely to be in the Northeast, then the West.

In age, the typical TV news director remained in the mid-40s. The median was 44 and the average was 45. Overall, the age ranged from 28 to 69. Generally, news directors were a little older in the largest markets and the largest stations, but the differences were quite small. Network affiliation and region made no difference.

News directors appeared to be getting a lot less nomadic. The typical TV news director had been at his or her station for just over 6 years (although not necessarily as news director). The average tenure at that station for the news director was 8½ years. One news director had been at the same station for 48 years. The numbers did not vary a lot by market size, although news directors in the very smallest markets tended to have been there a little less than for other markets. Overall, news directors were a little more stable in the Midwest and Northeast than in the South and West.

In radio, the median age for news directors was 48 and the average was 45. Interestingly, the average and median ages for news directors at commercial stations was about 10 years older than for those at noncommercial stations.

Radio news directors are even less nomadic than TV news directors. The typical (median) radio news director had been at his or her station for 6 years (although not necessarily as news director). The average tenure at that station for the news director was 10.3 years.

sec.title: About the Survey
sec.p: The RTDNA/Hofstra University survey was conducted in the fourth quarter of 2009 among all 1,770 operating, nonsatellite television stations, and a random sample of 4,000 radio stations. Valid responses came from 1,355 television stations (76.6%) and 203 radio news directors and GMs representing 301 radio stations.
Some data sets (e.g., the number of TV stations originating local news, getting it from others and women TV news directors) is based on a complete census and is not projected from a smaller sample.
